title: FirstFT: $9tn wiped off the value of US stocks this year
text:
US stocks have shed about $9tn this year as the Federal Reserve's attempt to rein in runaway inflation and mounting concerns over global growth sent investors dashing away from the world's biggest equities market.

The market value of the S&P 1500 index, a broad barometer of the US stock market, has tumbled from $45.8tn at the end of 2021 to $36.6tn by the end of trading yesterday on Wall Street, Bloomberg data show.

The benchmark S&P 500 index, which tracks shares in America's biggest companies, has slumped by about a fifth in 2022, leaving it on course to record its worst performance for the first six months of a year since 1970.

The slump in fortunes for investors was underlined yesterday by the world's leading central bankers who warned the era of low interest rates and moderate inflation is over.

Speaking at the European Central Bank's annual conference in Sintra, Portugal, Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell warned of “some pain” to come for developed economies as central banks try to tame raging inflation but said it would be worse if price rises went unchecked.

“The process is highly likely to involve some pain, but the worst pain would be from failing to address this high inflation and allowing it to become persistent,” he said.

In China, however, investors are more optimistic. The CSI 300 index of Shanghai- and Shenzhen-listed stocks is on course for the biggest monthly gain in almost two years. This week the government in Beijing halved the quarantine period for international travellers, raising hopes the worst of a lockdown-induced economic shock has passed.

There are also signs merger and acquisition activity is returning, with deals worth more than $10bn up 12 per cent in the first half of 2022 compared with the same period last year.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Exclusive: China lured graduate jobseekers into digital espionage Chinese university students have been lured to work at a secretive technology company to spy on western targets and translate hacked documents as part of Beijing's industrial-scale intelligence regime, a Financial Times investigation has found. Hainan Xiandun, a company alleged to have been a cover for Chinese hacking group APT40 by US authorities, was the recruitment agent.

2. Donald Trump's legal adviser subpoenaed by Jan 6 committee The congressional committee investigating last year's attack on the US Capitol has summoned Pat Cipollone following revelations about his role in the events of January 6 last year. Cassidy Hutchinson, a White House aide, depicted Cipollone as central to the insurrection in her testimony this week.

3. Grayscale launches lawsuit against SEC The crypto asset manager launched the legal action after the regulator rejected its application to convert a $40bn Bitcoin Trust into an exchange traded fund. The rejection comes as the SEC debates whether to allow US ETFs to hold bitcoin, rather than derivatives linked to the digital token, for the first time.

  • More bitcoin news: Three Arrows, the crypto hedge fund, which is based in Singapore and registered in the British Virgin Islands, has fallen into liquidation.

4. Ben & Jerry's criticises parent group Unilever over Israel sale The Vermont-based manufacturer said it disagrees with parent company Unilever's move to end a row over ice cream sales in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories by selling its business to a local licensee. The dispute has raised questions about the autonomy of Ben & Jerry's independent board.

5. Bed Bath & Beyond ousts chief The US home goods retailer announced the departure of its chief executive Mark Tritton yesterday, sending its share price down 24 per cent. Sue Gove, an independent director who joined Bed Bath & Beyond in 2019 from Target, will replace Tritton.

The day ahead

Xi Jinping arrives in Hong Kong The Chinese president has ventured outside mainland China for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic erupted in January 2020. He arrived in Hong Kong on the eve of the 25th anniversary of the former UK colony's return to Chinese sovereignty with China's first lady Peng Liyuan.

  • Go deeper Today's Big Read digs into the reinvention of Hong Kong after three stormy years.

Walgreens Boots Alliance earnings The pharmacy chain reports third-quarter results days after it announced it had abandoned the sale process for the Boots chain in the UK following upheaval in credit markets that resulted in bids below its expectations.

Spirit Airlines shareholders vote Ballots will be cast on a takeover by rival Frontier, initially announced in February, which would give the combined carrier an equity value of more than $4bn. Sujeet Indap explores the takeover battle for the US budget airline.

US Supreme Court The Supreme Court is expected to issue a landmark ruling on whether the Environmental Protection Agency can regulate greenhouse gas emissions from power stations on the final opinion day of the term. The court is also expected to issue a ruling on whether the Biden administration can lawfully end the “remain in Mexico” policy for migrants arriving at the southern border of the country, which was enacted by the Trump administration.

Economic data The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge — the core personal consumption expenditures price index — is forecast to have risen 0.4 per cent in May, according to economists polled by Refinitiv, up from 0.3 per cent in April. Economists also estimate the annual increase edged down to 4.8 per cent, from 4.9 per cent in April. New applications for unemployment aid are forecast to have edged down to 228,000 in the week ended June 25, from the previous week when they fell to 229,000.

What else we're reading

US baby formula crisis spurs market reform debate Abbott Laboratories, a $180bn healthcare company, is facing a political firestorm after a safety scandal forced it to shutter a Michigan plant, triggering an infant formula shortage and panic buying that forced Washington to approve emergency airlifts and drew scrutiny to a sector dominated by only two companies.

The fixer, the cheat and the corruption crisis in tennis Few sports are as tuned for cheating as tennis. From the sidelines, it can be difficult to distinguish a player who is having a bad day from one who is losing on purpose. That corruption lies at the heart of Nicolás Kicker's story.

Would carbon food labels change the way you shop? Environmentally friendly food shopping can be a challenge, as consumers demand “honest, transparent labelling of food”. Find out how your favourite UK supermarket items stack up in terms of carbon cost with our interactive scales.

Kylian Mbappé joins NFT craze The French footballer is following fellow superstars Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi into the world of non-fungible tokens, becoming an investor in SoftBank-backed fantasy football platform Sorare.

It's time to call a truce in the ‘war for talent' Business leaders love a dash of machismo glorifying their desk jobs but the “war for talent” makes me cringe, writes Emma Jacobs. This star system persists in some form in most organisations, she says, adding that the fetishisation of talent omits the work of their organisation or team.

Food & Drink

It's been a while since New York has had dynamic new restaurants, writes Jay Cheshes. But a wave of auteur operations, such as Bonnie's in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, are shaking up the dining scene.
